quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: The biggest misconception with tackling your speaking is that people grossly underestimate just how transformative it could be to your life. And the reason it's so transformative is because speaking is not a specialized skill, it's a meta skill. That means that the better you get at speaking, the better your life gets.

quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: Over the course of our life, because of all these little situations that happen, we start getting bugs in the software and we're not really upgrading our software. The moment you get the bugs and things start not working, we start avoiding, and suddenly we're not upgrading our software anymore. So we're stuck on old, buggy software. But the reality is, we have incredible software that we're evolved for this. So all we need to do is some debugging and some upgrading.

quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: I see enjoyment as a barometer, if I'm doing things right, I'm probably enjoying myself. If I'm doing things wrong, particularly with speaking, because this is something we're naturally evolved to do. So if we're naturally evolved to do it, it's not something that we dislike doing. It has to be something that rewards us. So as soon as things start not feeling enjoyable, it's a sign, hey, I'm probably doing this wrong.

quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: The day I understood that speaking was a subconscious flow-oriented process and not a conscious process, completely changed the way I approached it. Instead of thinking tactics and frameworks and adding more to the outside of the things I need to think about, when I realized when I speak best, I'm actually not thinking about speaking. I'm completely in tune with whatever it is I'm trying to convey. And the goal is to get into a flow state and stay in that flow state all the way through the finish line.

quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: Instead of counting my filler words, I started to try and figure out, what are the root causes that create these symptoms, and can I address those? The root cause of having lots of filler words or racing in your speaking, is that you probably struggle to feel comfortable slowing down, relaxing, or even pausing when your mind is racing and you feel pressure. Solve that, and not only do the filler words take care of themselves, but the racing takes care of itself and you suddenly have more mind space.

quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: People tend to give a great answer and then either they kind of taper off at the end, which doesn't leave you with a good impression, or they'll actively say the doubts that are coming up in their mind. It's like you had a very smooth flight across the Atlantic and your landing was absolutely horrible. You're not going to remember the smooth flight, you're going to remember the ending.

quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: People cannot see what you feel, even though it feels that way when you feel really, really strongly, but people can't see it. You're just looking like a normal speaker, competent and confident. But internally, it feels like everybody can see. So you're feeling all this insecurity and it feels like there's an elephant in the room. And so what most people do is they start leaking and they break character.

quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: The point of all of these games is to create turbulence. If you think about a pilot, a flight simulator, you don't put a pilot in a flight simulator and waste those precious hours having them just cruise at 30,000 feet in clear skies. You're going to say, now your motor just broke or you're going into crazy turbulence. So every one of these games have in common that we're creating turbulence for you.

quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: Pros are just amateurs who've learned to recover gracefully from their mistakes. And this is what we're trying to do here. If you know that you can recover from any mistake gracefully, then you're going to have confidence in any speaking scenario. And most of the scenarios you're going to be in are spontaneous, are ones you can't prepare for. So it's that much more important.

quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: If you think about somebody who you feel has great gravitas or great executive presence, they usually have something about them that's saying, this person really believes in what they're saying. The vast majority of people actually are not truly standing behind their words and their ideas. And what that does is that the people who speak a lot and feel a lot of conviction, their ideas go through more often than the others.

quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.text: Stop focusing as much on what you want to say and focus more on what you want your audience to remember. If you think about the last big meeting, the last talk you saw, you probably don't remember much. In fact, I wager you might only remember one thing from that talk. We call it the bow and arrow technique because we think you can only remember one thing out of a talk and it's very powerful to go through that framework when you're building a talk.

takeaways: Speaking is a meta skill, not a specialized one - improving it transforms your entire professional and personal life, much like fitness improves energy, confidence, and well-being beyond just physical health.

Focus on root causes, not symptoms - instead of counting filler words or memorizing tactics, address the underlying discomfort with pausing, slowing down, and trusting your subconscious ability to communicate.

Stay in character and end strong - audiences cannot see your internal nervousness, so leaking insecurities or hedging at the end of your points forces a negative lens onto people who otherwise thought you were doing great.

Practice through deliberate turbulence, not just repetition - games that create pressure and unpredictability build the resilience and adaptability needed for real-world spontaneous speaking scenarios.

Use the Accordion Method and Bow-and-Arrow to prepare talks - compress your content down to its essence through timed spoken reps, then expand back up intentionally, always anchored by the one thing you want your audience to remember.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the entire framework of tactical speaking advice - argues speaking is a subconscious flow process, not a conscious one, making most conventional tips counterproductive
Contradicts the common instinct to be authentic by showing your vulnerability - argues that sharing insecurities actively harms your credibility rather than building connection
Suggests that conviction matters more than correctness in getting ideas heard - challenges the meritocratic ideal that the best ideas win on their own
